introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.text: This web application is used to learn the calculation of probability with normal distributions. The tool includes the following functions.

learn.text: In this part you learn how to calculate probabilities with normal distributions. Interactive diagrams and explanations convey the topic in an understandable and playful way.

application.title: Areas of application
application.text: The measured values of many processes in natural science, economics and engineering are approximately normally distributed. The normal distribution is therefore used in many areas to describe data and their probabilities. This page presents a field in which normal distributions are used.

sections.title: Financial Markets
sections.text: A central task of fund and asset managers is risk management. When trades are executed, a balance must always be struck between return and risk. Both variables are influenced by price fluctuations. It is often assumed that price fluctuations are normally distributed. This allows analysts to calculate the probabilities that certain events will occur. For example, the probability that a security will fall by 10% within the next few days could be calculated. Using historical prices, the mean and standard deviation of price changes can be calculated. By applying the normal distribution and the calculations explained in this application, risks can then be quantified and investment decisions optimized. tasks.text: Peter walks an average of 500 meters to the university every morning. Since he does not always use the optimal path, his path has a standard deviation of 10 meters. The path to the university can be considered normally distributed. Calculate the probability that Peter's path is shorter than 485 meters.

It is estimated that about 8% of all students graduate with a bachelor's degree each year. A university in Frankfurt has 20,000 students and wants to order champagne for the graduates. What is the probability that at least 1350 bottles of sparkling wine will be needed? The standard deviation is 38.

Peter walks an average of 500 meters to the university every morning. Since he does not always use the optimal path, his path has a standard deviation of 10 meters. Calculate the probability that the path is at most 501 meters and at least 499 meters long.

It is estimated that about 8% of all students graduate with a bachelor's degree each year. A university in Frankfurt has 20,000 students and wants to order champagne for the graduates. With what probability does the number of meters required deviate from the expected value by no more than the standard deviation?
